The Oregon Country, encompassing present-day Oregon, Washington, and parts of Idaho, Wyoming, and British Columbia, was jointly occupied by the United States and Great Britain under the Treaty of 1818. This agreement allowed both countries to settle and trade in the region, avoiding conflict over territorial claims.

The joint occupation lasted until 1846 when the Oregon Treaty was signed, establishing the 49th parallel as the boundary between the United States and British North America (Canada). This resolved the dispute over the Oregon Country and solidified the U.S. ownership of the southern portion while Britain retained control of the northern part.

The British referred to the region as the Columbia District, while the Americans called it Oregon Country.
